awd_titl_txt: Modeling, Analysis and Control Design for Spatially Distributed Systems with Application to Wind Farms
awd_abstract_narration:
This work will address challenges arising in the modeling and control of wind farms, enabling power grid operators both to accurately predict capacity under varying operating conditions, as well as to track a desired power output profile. In contrast to controllers that simply maximize output power, this enhanced operational flexibility will allow wind farms to support utilities with valuable services such as frequency regulation and power ramping. The key technical innovation of this project is a reduced-order model that accurately captures dynamic interaction between turbines and the effect of turbine wakes, while remaining tractable enough for real-time computation. The model and controls will be tested using high-fidelity wind farm simulations and actual operator data. The tools to be created will help improve the economic competitiveness of wind power as a core component of the electric power system. The project will provide interdisciplinary research training to graduate students, focusing on the interplay between wind farm flow physics and control theory, and including international research opportunities. The project includes outreach to Baltimore high schools and a STEM summer program for high school students at the Johns Hopkins University.  

This project will create models, control algorithms and simulation tools for multiscale systems in which mechanical devices must perform coordinated actions within an infinite (or high) dimensional process, with specific application to wind farms. The research goals of the project are as follows: (i) computationally tractable methods to capture the complex interactions between turbines, and to bridge the gap between overly simplified static wake models and slow, costly high-dimensional models; (ii) a model-based control framework to move beyond the traditional control goal of maximum power extraction, and facilitate more complex trajectory tracking; (iii) extension of current high-fidelity simulation tools to be suitable for wind farm model validation and control algorithm testing and refinement; (iv) combined wind farm modeling and control tool development based on a grid simulation system that generates frequency control trajectories and acts as a supervisory control entity to distribute the control objectives over multiple wind farms. The project will provide a large eddy simulation (LES) based model and control validation platform that can facilitate modular changes in wind turbine and wake models along with the control algorithms, so that new models and flow control strategies can be efficiently tested. The new platform will support the coordination of multiple wind farms participating in frequency regulation services, using an interconnected simulated power grid as a supervisory system.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to develop a suite of models that improve wind farm power output prediction under a wide range of wind farm operating conditions. Models were leveraged in control algorithms that enabled wind farms to track a power signal and use aerodynamic energy storage to participate in existing and emerging energy markets (e.g. secondary frequency regulation markets).  In contrast to traditional wind farm control approaches that sought to maximize output power, this enhanced operational flexibility will allow wind farms to support utilities with valuable services such as frequency regulation and power ramping. The project advanced the creation of a large eddy simulation (LES) based model and control validation platform that facilitates modular changes in wind turbine and wake models along with the control algorithms, so that new models and flow control strategies can be efficiently tested.

 Intellectual Merits: The key technical innovations of this project include a suite of reduced-order models that accurately capture the dynamic interaction between turbines and the effect of turbine wakes. The suite of models includes: an area localized model (ALC) model that extends the coupled wake and top-down modeling paradigm to arbitrary wind farm arrangements. A Voronoi tessellation of the farm defines a local area around each turbine to enable local assessment of the top-down model and planform skin-friction coefficients that help provide better inputs to the coupled wake model, see included figure. A first principles approach to capturing the downstream effects of a yawed turbine overcomes limitations of previous approaches and has the potential to change the way this phenomenon is modeled in both layout design and control applications. The theoretical development has also included insight that led to an actuator disk model correction for large-eddy simulation codes that enables one to obtain the expected power curve from axial-momentum theory for various grid resolutions and filter widths. This will improve the accuracy of state-of-the-art simulation tools without an increase in computational burden.

The project also demonstrated that it is possible to use a large wind farm to provide power grid services, such as secondary frequency regulation. The multidisciplinary approach that combines a model of the fluid dynamics in the wind farm array (in particular, an advection/diffusion model for the wake evolution) with a receding horizon control approach for tracking a power level trajectory performs more efficiently than discipline specific approaches, see figure attached.  The use of the fluids models within the control scheme leads to lower set point reductions than the up-regulation requirements. Such models also improve the efficiency of the control, thereby making wind farm participation in frequency regulation markets more financially viable (i.e., it lowers the opportunity cost of lost bulk power revenue). A proof-of-concept estimation algorithm was also developed and tested that lead to a dynamic model for wind farm power output prediction under changing wind farm directions, see attached figure.

Broader Impacts: The tools to be created will help improve the economic competitiveness of wind power as a core component of the electric power system. The project has provided interdisciplinary research training to graduate students, focusing on the interplay between wind farm flow physics and control theory, and including international research opportunities.

The project included outreach to Baltimore high schools and a STEM summer program for high school students at the Johns Hopkins University. Specifically, the outreach activities consisted of lectures at the JHU?s Engineering Innovation program and in lower level engineering classes. Spring break and intersession activities associated with the STEM partnership between Barclay Elementary/Middle School and Johns Hopkins University?s Whiting School of Engineering (https://engineering.jhu.edu/outreach/barclay-school-partnership/) are helping to educate future STEM college students. Finally, PI Gayme?s participation in the inaugural US version of Pint of Science at a local bar provided an interactive venue to explain wind energy and how wind farms can be controlled to provide power grid support to a broad local audience.
